facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 128 of 1960 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 4, 1955, of the Punjab High Court in R. S. A. No. 493 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 128 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 4, 1955, of the Punjab High Court in R. S. A. No. 493 of 1950.

facts.text: The subject-matter of the appeal is land measuring 9 kanals and 2 marlas bearing Khasra Nos. 292 and 296 in mauza Kot Syed Mahmud, in the District of Amritsar, previous corresponding Khasra Nos. 324 and 328.

anchor.surface_text: The subject-matter of the appeal is land measuring 9 kanals and 2 marlas bearing Khasra Nos. 292 and 296 in mauza Kot Syed Mahmud,in the District of Amritsar the previous companyresponding Khasra Nos. of the land were 324 and 328.

facts.text: The land originally belonged to a number of co-sharers, including Teja Singh and Jhandha Singh.

anchor.surface_text: This land formed part of a larger area which originally belonged to a number of companysharers, including Teja Singh and jhandha Singh.

facts.text: There was a partition among the co-sharers.

anchor.surface_text: There was a partition among the said company sharers and pursuant to that partition, on April 20, 1929 an application was filed before the Revenue Authorities for mutation of the names in accordance with the terms of the partition

facts.text: On April 20, 1929, an application was filed before the Revenue Authorities for mutation of names in accordance with the partition terms, signed by all co-sharers including Teja Singh and Jhandha Singh.

anchor.surface_text: There was a partition among the said company sharers and pursuant to that partition, on April 20, 1929 an application was filed before the Revenue Authorities for mutation of the names in accordance with the terms of the partition and the petition was signed by all the company sharers including Teja Singh and jhandha Singh.

facts.text: The petition (Ex. D-6) stated that in respect of the Khasra numbers one share should be entered in the name of Teja Singh and 7 shares in the name of Jhandha Singh.

anchor.surface_text: It was stated in the petition, marked as Ex.D-6 in the case, that in respect of the said Khasra numbers one share should be entered in the name of Teja Singh and 7 shares in the name of jhandha Singh. This fact is number admitted.

facts.text: Mutation effected on August 26, 1929 (mutation No. 960) showed the entire extent of the Khasra numbers against Teja Singh alone.

anchor.surface_text: But in the mutation that was effected on August 26, 1929 the entire extent of the said Khasra numbers was shown against Teja Singh alone. The mutation number was 960.

facts.text: On August 10, 1934, Jhandha Singh applied to Revenue Authorities to correct the mistake in revenue record.

anchor.surface_text: On August 10, 1934, jhandha Singh, discovering the mistake companymitted in the revenue record, applied to the Revenue Authorities for companyrecting the said mistake.

facts.text: Revenue Authorities enquired into the matter from August 10, 1934, to October 31, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: The Revenue Authorities enquired into the matter from August 10, 1934, to October 31. 1935.

facts.text: Mula Singh, brother and heir of Teja Singh (Teja Singh died), admitted the mistake in revenue record before the authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The record of that enquiry discloses that Mula Singh, the brother of Teja Singh-Teja Singh died and Mula Singh was his heir-admitted the mistake made in the revenue record before the companycerned authorities.

facts.text: Revenue Authorities had a report of enquiry by subordinate officer tracing history of Khasra numbers, partition, and joint application for mutation.

anchor.surface_text: That apart, they had before them a report of the enquiry made by a subordinate officer of the revenue department tracing the history of the said Khasra numbers and also giving the relevant facts, namely, the partition between the companysharers and the joint Application filed by them for mutation of their names in respect of the plots allotted to each one of them.

facts.text: Revenue Authorities corrected the mistake; mutation No. 1490 entered 1/8 share for Teja Singh and 7/8 for Jhandha Singh.

anchor.surface_text: On the material so-placed before them, the Revenue Authorities companyrected the mistake, and against mutation ,No. 1490 the companyrect shares of Teja Singh and Jhandha Singh, namely, 1/8 and 7/8 respectively were given.

facts.text: On October 24, 1934, Mula Singh executed a sale deed conveying the land (Khasra 324 and 328) to Gurbaksh Singh, the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On October 24, 1934, i.e., after jhandha ,Singh had filed the application for companyrecting the mutation No. 960, Mula Singh executed a sale deed companyveying the said land bearing Khasra numbers 324 and 328 in favour of Gurbaksh Singh, the appellant,

facts.text: The sale deed was executed on the day Mula Singh had to appear before Revenue Authorities.

anchor.surface_text: i.e., on the very date when Mula Singh had to appear before the Revenue Authorities.

facts.text: Appellant obtained a security bond from Mula Singh to indemnify against any loss in respect of the property.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant obtained a security bond from Mula Singh to indemnify him against any loss that might be caused to him in respect of the said property

facts.text: Appellant paid the bulk of consideration only on October 22, 1937, after three years of the sale deed.

anchor.surface_text: he also paid the bulk of the companysideration only on October 22, 1937, i.e., after three years of the sale deed.

facts.text: Jhandha Singh sold his 7/8 share to Gopal Singh, from whom Nikka Singh (first respondent) purchased by sale deed dated October 27, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: jhandha Singh in his turn sold his 7/8 share in the said Khasra numbers, along with others, to Gopal Singh from whom Nikka Singh, the first respondent, purchased the said share by a sale deed dated October 27, 1936.

facts.text: Appellant filed suit under s.117 Punjab Land Revenue Act for declaration of exclusive title to the two Khasra numbers; defendants Nikka Singh (r1) and Mula Singh (r2).

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed a suit under s. 117 of the Punjab Land Revenue Act, 1887, out of which the present appeal arises, in the revenue companyrt for a declaration of his exclusive title to the said two Khasra numbers, and in that suit Nikka Singh, the first respondent, and Mula Singh, the second respondent, were the defendants.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Amritsar, decreed appellant's suit on February 14, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: It would be enough if we start with the decision of the Subordinate judge dated February 14, 1949, to whose file the suit was transferred from the file of the revenue companyrt by the District judge after it was remanded by the High Court on an earlier occasion.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge held mutation 1490 not properly made as based on admission by Mula after sale to plaintiff, no facts proved.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate judge expressed his opinion on the relevant issue thus so far as the land in suit is companycerned., Mula Singh had sold it to the plaintiff on 24th October, 1934, and any admission by him made on 10th August, 1936 would number affect the plaintiff. ... The mutation entry 1490 was therefore number properly made

facts.text: District Judge dismissed appeal finding appellant bona fide purchaser in good faith, no definite finding on title.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the learned District judge, though he made certain observations indicating his line of thought, did number give any definite finding on the question of title, but he dismissed the appeal on the finding that the appellant was a bona fide purchaser in good faith.

facts.text: High Court in second appeal set aside Subordinate Judge decree, dismissed suit, holding correction of mutation 960 with consent, presumption of correctness, appellant cognizant of real state (Mula had 1/8).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the companyrection of the earlier mutation No. 960 was made with the companysent of both the parties and there is a presumption attached to the companyrectness of the later mutation and that the appellant was fully companynizant of the real state of affairs, namely, that Mula Singh had only 1/8 share in the said Khasra numbers.

facts.text: Appellant and Mula Singh belong to the same village Kot Syed Mahmud.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and Mula Singh belong to the same village Kot Syed Mahmud.

facts.text: Supreme Court held appellant not bona fide purchaser in good faith, had knowledge of defect in Mula's title.

anchor.surface_text: These facts show that the appellant had knowledge of the defect in the title of Mula Singh. It is, therefore, number possible to hold that he had purchased it in good faith.

facts.text: Mutation entry 1490 made in accordance with facts proved before Revenue Authorities (Mula's evidence, subordinate officer's report including Ex. D-6), presumption of correctness under s.37 Punjab Land Revenue Act; appellant failed to rebut.

anchor.surface_text: It must, there fore, be held that the provisions of s. 37 a  of the Punjab Land Revenue Act were satisfied. If so, there is a presumption that the later entry was companyrect. The appellant did number adduce any evidence to rebut the said presumption.

issues.text: Whether the High Court had jurisdiction under ss. 100 and 101 of the Code of Civil Procedure to set aside concurrent findings arrived at by the two lower courts.

anchor.surface_text: 1 The High Court has no jurisdiction under ss. 100 and 101 of the Code of Civil Procedure to set aside concurrent findings arrived at by the two lower courts.  2  Under s. 37 of the Punjab Land Revenue Act there is a presumption in favour of an entry

issues.text: Whether there is a presumption in favour of mutation entry No. 1490 under s. 37 of the Punjab Land Revenue Act given that it was corrected based on Mula Singh's admission after he transferred his interest to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: 2  Under s. 37 of the Punjab Land Revenue Act there is a presumption in favour of an entry in the revenue record if it is made in accordance with the facts proved or admitted to have occurred but, as in the present case the entry was corrected on the admission of Mula Singh after he transferred his interest in favour of the appellant, the said admission could not constitute a legal basis for the said entry and therefore no presumption under that section would attach to that entry.

issues.text: Whether the appellant was a bona fide purchaser in good faith under s. 41 of the Transfer of Property Act.

anchor.surface_text: Nor did the District judge consider the impact of the provisions of s. 41 of the Transfer of Property Act on the facts of the case. Such a finding arrived at without evidence and without applying the correct principles of law cannot obviously bind the High Court. Section 41 of the Transfer of Property Act reads Where, with the consent, express or implied, of the persons interested in immoveable property, a person is the ostensible owner of such property and transfers the same for consideration, the transfer shall not be voidable on the ground that the transferor was not authorised to make it provided that the transferee, after taking reasonable care to ascertain that the transferor had power to make the transfer, has acted in good faith.

arguments.claim: Mutation entry 1490 was not properly made under Section 37 of the Land Revenue Act as it was based on admission by Mula Singh after the sale to the plaintiff and no facts had been proved before the attesting officer.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate judge expressed his opinion on the relevant issue thus so far as the land in suit is concerned., Mula Singh had sold it to the plaintiff on 24th October, 1934, and any admission by him made on 10th August, 1936 would not affect the plaintiff. Under Section 37 of the Land Revenue Act, a mutation can be based either on facts proved or admitted.

arguments.claim: The appellant was a bona fide purchaser in good faith.

arguments.claim: General rule is person cannot confer better title than he has; s.41 TPA is exception requiring onus on transferee to prove ostensible owner, reasonable care, good faith.

anchor.surface_text: The general rule is that a person cannot confer a better title than he has. This section is an exception to that rule. Being an exception, the onus certainly is on the transferee to show that the transferor was the ostensible owner of the property

holdings.text: The High Court had jurisdiction under ss. 100 and 101 CPC to interfere as the District Judge gave no definite finding on title and his good faith finding was ipse dixit without evidence or law.

anchor.surface_text: 1 The High Court has no jurisdiction under ss. 100 and 101 of the Code of Civil Procedure to set aside concurrent findings arrived at by the two lower courts. ... Such a finding arrived at without evidence and without applying the correct principles of law cannot obviously bind the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: District Judge avoided title issue, disposed on unsupported good faith finding without s.41 TPA analysis; not binding on High Court.

holdings.text: Appellant was not a bona fide purchaser in good faith under s.41 TPA as facts show knowledge of title defect in Mula Singh's claim.

anchor.surface_text: Nor did the District judge consider the impact of the provisions of s. 41 of the Transfer of Property Act on the facts of the case. Such a finding ... These facts show that the appellant had knowledge of the defect in the title of Mula Singh. It is, therefore, not possible to hold that he had purchased it in good faith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Same village, sale on revenue enquiry date, security bond for indemnity, delayed payment 3 years indicate awareness of dispute; onus on transferee not discharged.

holdings.text: Mutation entry No.1490 attracts presumption of correctness under ss.37 and 44 PLRA as made in accordance with proved facts (Mula Singh evidence, subordinate report incl. Ex.D-6); appellant failed to rebut.

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we see any merits in the contention that no presumption can be drawn in favour of the correctness of the impugned entry ... The High Court was, therefore, right in holding that there was a presumption in favour of the correctness of the entry and the appellant had failed to rebut the same.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.37(a) satisfied by enquiry evidence beyond Mula's admission alone; s.44 presumption applies unless rebutted; Ex.D-6 confirms partition shares.

justification_sets.label: Transfer of Property Act s.41 support

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court judgment upheld; no declaration of exclusive title to appellant; presumption in favour of revenue entry No. 1490 upheld
